Two semifields are {\it strongly isotopic} if they are isotopic via the triple $(F,G,I)$, where $I$ denotes the identity map. Note that this definition varies in the literature, with one of $F$ or $G$ sometimes being take to be the identity instead of $H$.

Here we identify the field element $\alpha$ with the map $x \mapsto \alpha x$. Note that juxtaposition denotes composition, i.e. $(f \alpha) (x) = f(\alpha x)$. These spreads have been used to define some very useful geometric invariants for finite semifields, in particular in the case of semifields two-dimensional over a nucleus. 
See for example \cite{CAPOTR2004}, \cite{MaPoTr2007}.

For a spread ${\mathcal D}$, we will write $B_{{\mathcal D}}(f)$ for the unique element of ${\mathcal D}$ containing $f$. For a subset $U$ of ${\mathrm{PG}}(E,q)$, we denote $B_{{\mathcal D}}(U) = \{B_{{\mathcal D}}(f):f \in U\}$.

The {\it Segre variety} $S_{n,n}(q)$ in ${\mathrm{PG}}(E,q)$ is the image of the Segre map,
and corresponds to the points defined by rank one endomorphisms. The points of the Segre variety can be partitioned into maximum subspaces in two ways. We denote these two families of maximal subspaces by ${\mathcal F}_l$ and ${\mathcal F}_r$, where ${\mathcal F}_i$ is contained in ${\mathcal D}_i$ for $i \in \{r,l\}$. We have the following lemma.

\begin{lemma}
\label{lem:goodspread}
Suppose ${\mathcal D}$ is a Desarguesian spread of ${\mathrm{PG}}(E,q)$ containing ${\mathcal F}_r$ (resp. ${\mathcal F}_l$). Then there exists an invertible  $X \in E$ such that ${\mathcal D}$ is of the form ${\mathcal D}_{r,X}$ (resp. $D_{l,X})$, where

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle:=\{\langle f\alpha:\alpha\in{\mathbb{F}_{q^{n}}}\rangle:f\in E^{%
\times}\}" display="inline"><mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>f</mi><mi>α</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>α</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>𝔽</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>:</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>∈</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>×</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle{\mathcal{D}}_{l}" display="inline"><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒟</mi><mi>l</mi></msub></math>

\times}\}." display="inline"><mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>α</mi><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi>α</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>𝔽</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>:</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>∈</mo><msup><mi>E</mi><mo>×</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex25.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w(x)=\sum_{j=0}^{n-1}w_{j}x^{q^{j}}=\underline{x}w^{T}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>j</mi></msup></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder accentunder="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>¯</mo></munder><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>w</mi><mi>T</mi></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Now $n$-dimensional algebras over ${{\mathbb{F}}_q}$ are in one-to-one correspondence with tensors in the space $V^{\vee} \otimes V^{\vee} \otimes V$. See \cite{Lavrauw2011} for details regarding tensors and semifields. 

A {\it fundamental tensor} is a tensor of the form $T = \underline{a}^{\vee} \otimes \underline{b}^{\vee} \otimes \underline{c}$. The tensor product space is generated by the fundamental tensors. The {\it tensor rank} of a tensor $T$ is the minimum number of fundamental tensors needed to span a subspace containing $T$. 



The tensor rank of a semifield ${\mathbb{S}}$ was defined in \cite{Lavrauw2011} as the tensor rank of a corresponding tensor. We now compare this to the BEL-rank, by viewing both as ranks with respect to different sets in the same space. 

A fundamental tensor $T = \underline{a}^{\vee} \otimes \underline{b}^{\vee} \otimes \underline{c}$ defines an algebra with multiplication $T(\underline{x},\underline{y}) = \underline{a}^{\vee}(\underline{x})\underline{b}^{\vee}(\underline{y})\underline{c}$. Abusing notation, this gives a multiplication on ${\mathbb{F}_{q^n}}$ defined by

nexttext:
for some linear map $f$. We note that semifields with multiplication of the form $xy + {\mathrm{Tr}}(f(x)y)$, where ${\mathrm{Tr}}$ denotes the absolute trace function, have been studied in \cite{HoOzZh}, where it is shown that with certain restrictions on $q$ and $n$, all such semifields are isotopic to a field. The case where the trace function is taken to a non-prime field is left open. These examples, together with the examples of order $5^4$ noted in the preceding subsection, are the first non-trivial examples of semifields of this form.

We can see from the table below that there are many examples where ${\mathrm{brk}}({\mathbb{S}}) \ne {\mathrm{brk}}({\mathbb{S}}^d)$. Note also that semifields in orbit XIV are three-dimensional over one nucleus, and six-dimensional over the other two nuclei. The BEL-rank of a semifield in this Knuth-orbit is either $2$ or $4$. Hence we can have an example of a semifield such that ${\mathrm{brk}}({\mathbb{S}}) > l$, where $l$ is the dimension of ${\mathbb{S}}$ over its left nucleus.
